answer: The builders faced numerous obstacles in attempting to have dirigibles dock at the Empire State Building. The architects of late 1920s and 1930s New York had ambitious plans to transform air travel and position the city as a pioneer in modern transportation. However, their grand ideas failed to materialize as expected. In an effort to surpass the Chrysler Building, architect Al Smith added a precarious mast to the top of the Empire State Building. This mast was intended to serve as a docking station for blimps, allowing passengers to embark and disembark, as well as refuel. Despite the hype surrounding this innovative concept, safety concerns loomed large. Most blimps outside the United States used highly flammable hydrogen instead of helium. Had a disaster like the explosion of the German airship "Hindenburg" occurred over a densely populated area like New York, the consequences would have been catastrophic. The architects also underestimated the impact of weather conditions on the stability of the mast. Even when tethered, a blimp would still sway in the wind, making docking a risky endeavor. The U.S. Navy attempted to dock next to the mast before regulations prohibited aircraft from flying at such low altitudes, but their efforts were thwarted by the unpredictable winds. While the architects of the 1920s and 1930s aimed for groundbreaking achievements, they ultimately encountered insurmountable challenges that prevented their vision from becoming a reality.

These obstacles made the idea of allowing dirigibles to dock at the Empire State Building unfeasible and against the law.

Hydrogen, being highly flammable, led to safety concerns. This was exemplified by the tragic explosion of the German dirigible Hindenburg on May 6, 1937, in Lakehurst, New Jersey.  As a result of such incidents, the popularity of dirigibles for transportation waned by the late 1930s. Instead, repurposing the dirigibles' passenger compartments for commercial use, the world's largest soda fountain and tea garden were created. The era of dirigibles as a mode of transport had come to an end, with their legacy living on in other innovative ways.
